title: EU's Critical Raw Materials Act: Transforming Europe's Supply Chain Security - Discovery Alert
description:
Strategic Raw Materials vs Critical Raw Materials Classification The critical raw materials act distinguishes between strategic and critical raw materials based on economic importance, supply risk, and substitutability factors.
The 65% Third-Country Dependency Limit The 65% threshold represents the maximum acceptable level of dependence on any single third country for critical materials supply.
China's Dominant Position in Critical Materials Processing China currently controls significant portions of global critical materials processing capacity, particularly for rare earth elements, battery materials, and specialised alloys.
The strategic materials list includes rare earth elements, lithium, cobalt, nickel, and other materials critical for batteries, renewable energy systems, and digital technologies.
Future critical materials may include quantum computing components, advanced energy storage materials, and specialised alloys for aerospace applications.
text:
European raw materials legislation is fundamentally reshaping how the continent approaches resource security and supply chain independence, with implications extending far beyond traditional trade policies. The critical raw materials act represents the EU's most ambitious attempt at achieving strategic autonomy in the 21st century, addressing vulnerabilities that have become increasingly apparent amid rising geopolitical tensions.

What Is the EU's Critical Raw Materials Act and Why Does It Matter?

The Critical Raw Materials Act (CRMA) represents the EU's most comprehensive legislative response to supply chain vulnerabilities that have plagued European industries for decades. This landmark regulation, which came into force in 2024, establishes binding targets across all 27 EU member states and fundamentally reframes how Europe approaches resource security.

Legislative Framework and Strategic Objectives

At its core, the CRMA addresses three critical dimensions of resource independence through legally binding numerical targets. The legislation mandates that by 2030, the EU must achieve domestic extraction of 10% of its critical raw materials needs, establish processing capacity for 40% of requirements, and implement recycling systems capable of recovering 25% of essential materials.

The strategic objectives extend beyond mere numerical compliance. European policymakers designed the framework to reduce dangerous dependencies on single-source suppliers, particularly in sectors where supply disruptions could cripple entire industries. Furthermore, the regulation acknowledges that Europe's industrial competitiveness depends fundamentally on secure access to materials essential for clean energy transitions, digital infrastructure, and defence capabilities.

Timeline and Implementation Status

Implementation follows a structured timeline with specific milestones and measurement points. The 2030 targets serve as the primary benchmark, however, intermediate assessments will monitor progress and adjust policies as needed. Member states must coordinate their national strategies with EU-wide objectives, creating a complex web of regulatory requirements and compliance mechanisms.

According to Aurubis CEO Toralf Haag, whose company represents Europe's largest copper producer, early implementation discussions with EU authorities have proven challenging. Haag noted that while the company anticipates positive long-term effects for the sector, the regulatory negotiation process has been particularly demanding as industries work to align operational realities with policy objectives.

Key Performance Indicators and Benchmarks

The CRMA establishes measurable performance indicators that will determine success or failure of the regulatory framework. These include specific material availability ratios, processing capacity utilisation rates, recycling efficiency metrics, and supply chain diversification indices. Regular monitoring will assess whether the targets translate into genuine strategic autonomy or merely statistical compliance.

The European Commission will evaluate progress through comprehensive stress testing, supply chain risk assessments, and regular reporting from member states and key industrial players. Consequently, this monitoring system aims to provide early warning signals if dependencies on third countries exceed acceptable thresholds or if domestic capacity development falls behind schedule.

How Will the CRMA Transform Europe's Raw Materials Independence by 2030?

Europe's path to raw materials independence relies on a carefully calibrated balance between domestic production expansion, processing infrastructure development, and circular economy optimisation. The transformation requires unprecedented coordination between public policy, private investment, and technological innovation.

The 10-40-25 Formula Explained

The numerical framework represents more than arbitrary targets; it reflects a strategic assessment of what constitutes achievable yet meaningful progress toward resource security. The 10% domestic extraction target acknowledges geological realities while pushing for expanded mining activities in regions with viable deposits. Meanwhile, the 40% processing capacity goal addresses the critical bottleneck where raw materials are refined into usable industrial inputs.

CRMA Target Percentage Current EU Performance Gap to Close Domestic Extraction 10% Varies by material (2-8%) Significant expansion needed Processing Capacity 40% Limited (5-15% typical) Major infrastructure investment required Recycling Achievement 25% Mixed (10-60% depending on material) Technology and collection improvements essential

The 25% recycling target may prove most achievable in the near term, as it builds on existing circular economy initiatives and requires less capital-intensive infrastructure compared to mining or processing facilities. However, as Aurubis leadership emphasised, keeping recycling materials within European borders remains a critical challenge requiring export restrictions and customs duties to prevent material outflows.

Strategic Raw Materials vs Critical Raw Materials Classification

The critical raw materials act distinguishes between strategic and critical raw materials based on economic importance, supply risk, and substitutability factors. Strategic raw materials include those essential for emerging technologies and defence applications, while critical raw materials encompass a broader range of materials vital for industrial production.

This classification system determines regulatory priorities, funding allocation, and policy interventions. For instance, materials classified as strategic receive enhanced protection through export controls, stockpiling requirements, and preferential access to EU funding programmes. The distinction also influences trade policy, with strategic materials subject to more restrictive export licensing and foreign investment screening.

Supply Chain Diversification Requirements

Diversification mandates require companies to demonstrate resilience against supply disruptions through multiple sourcing strategies, alternative material development, and geographic distribution of suppliers. Large companies must conduct supply chain due diligence and develop contingency plans for critical material shortages.

The diversification approach recognises that complete self-sufficiency remains unrealistic for many materials. Instead, the strategy focuses on reducing dangerous over-reliance on single suppliers or regions while building robust networks of alternative sources across different geopolitical zones.

Which Industries Stand to Benefit Most from CRMA Implementation?

The regulatory framework creates distinct advantages for industries positioned to capitalise on enhanced supply chain security, domestic processing capacity, and recycling infrastructure development. Early beneficiaries will likely be companies with existing European operations and established relationships with EU policymakers.

Clean Energy Technology Manufacturers

Renewable energy equipment manufacturers stand to benefit significantly from guaranteed access to critical materials like rare earth elements, lithium, and specialised alloys. The critical minerals energy transition focus on processing capacity development could reduce costs and delivery times for companies producing wind turbines, solar panels, and energy storage systems.

European companies in this sector will gain competitive advantages over non-EU rivals who may face export restrictions or higher costs when sourcing materials from European recycling streams. Furthermore, the regulatory framework essentially creates a protected market for clean energy materials, supporting the EU's broader climate objectives.

Automotive and Battery Production Sectors

Electric vehicle manufacturers and battery producers represent primary beneficiaries of critical raw materials act implementation, particularly regarding lithium, cobalt, nickel, and graphite supply chains. The regulation's emphasis on recycling could create cost-effective sources of battery materials while reducing reliance on geopolitically sensitive mining regions.

Automotive companies with European production facilities will benefit from enhanced material security and potentially lower input costs as domestic processing capacity expands. Additionally, the regulatory framework supports the industry's transition to electric mobility by addressing one of the most significant supply chain vulnerabilities.

Electronics and Digital Infrastructure Companies

Semiconductor manufacturers, telecommunications equipment producers, and digital infrastructure companies require stable access to specialty metals and rare earth elements. The CRMA's processing capacity targets could establish European sources for materials currently dominated by Asian suppliers.

These industries will particularly benefit from battery recycling initiatives, as electronic waste contains significant concentrations of valuable materials that can be recovered and reprocessed. The regulatory framework's focus on circular economy principles aligns well with electronics industry sustainability goals.

Defence and Aerospace Applications

Military and aerospace industries require materials with specific performance characteristics and secure supply chains free from geopolitical interference. The CRMA's strategic materials classification provides enhanced protection for defence-critical materials through export controls and stockpiling requirements.

European defence contractors will benefit from guaranteed access to specialty alloys, rare earth elements, and other materials essential for advanced weapons systems, aircraft, and space technology. Consequently, the regulatory framework supports European strategic autonomy objectives in defence procurement.

What Are the Key Regulatory Mechanisms Driving CRMA Success?

The CRMA's effectiveness depends on sophisticated regulatory mechanisms that streamline approvals, coordinate member state actions, and provide targeted support for strategic projects. These mechanisms represent significant departures from traditional EU regulatory approaches.

Streamlined Permitting Processes and Timeline Reductions

The streamlined permitting reforms aim to reduce approval timelines for mining, processing, and recycling facilities through coordinated procedures and standardised requirements across member states. The regulatory framework establishes clear deadlines for permitting decisions and creates fast-track procedures for strategic projects.

Extraction Permit Timeline Target: 24-27 Months

The CRMA establishes ambitious targets for permitting timeline reductions, aiming to process extraction permits within 24-27 months compared to current procedures that often require 5-10 years for complex projects.

These timeline reductions require significant changes in member state regulatory procedures, enhanced coordination between different approval authorities, and streamlined environmental impact assessments. The success of permitting reforms will largely determine whether the 2030 targets remain achievable.

Strategic Project Designation and State Aid Flexibility

Projects receiving strategic designation benefit from enhanced state aid flexibility, expedited approvals, and preferential access to EU funding programmes. The designation process considers economic importance, supply chain impact, and contribution to EU strategic objectives.

State aid flexibility allows member states to provide financial support that would normally violate EU competition rules, recognising that strategic autonomy objectives may require temporary market interventions. This mechanism provides crucial support for projects that deliver public benefits but may not be commercially viable without assistance.

Each member state must establish single points of contact to coordinate CRMA implementation, facilitate cross-border projects, and ensure consistent application of regulatory requirements. These coordination mechanisms aim to prevent bureaucratic fragmentation that could undermine policy effectiveness.

The single point of contact system enables companies to navigate complex multi-jurisdictional requirements through centralised coordination rather than separate negotiations with multiple national authorities. This approach particularly benefits projects spanning multiple member states or requiring coordinated supply chain development.

How Does the CRMA Address Supply Chain Vulnerabilities?

Supply chain resilience forms the foundation of the CRMA's strategic approach, recognising that Europe's industrial competitiveness depends on reliable access to essential materials. The regulatory framework addresses vulnerabilities through diversification requirements, monitoring systems, and protective measures.

The 65% Third-Country Dependency Limit

The 65% threshold represents the maximum acceptable level of dependence on any single third country for critical materials supply. When dependencies exceed this limit, the EU must implement corrective measures including alternative sourcing, domestic capacity development, or strategic stockpiling.

This mechanism provides objective criteria for identifying dangerous dependencies before they create systemic vulnerabilities. Furthermore, the threshold applies to both primary materials and processed products, ensuring that supply chain security extends throughout the value chain rather than focusing solely on raw material extraction.

Stress Testing and Risk Monitoring Requirements

Regular stress testing evaluates supply chain resilience under various scenarios including geopolitical tensions, natural disasters, trade disputes, and market volatility. These assessments identify potential failure points and inform policy responses before disruptions occur.

Risk monitoring systems track supply chain indicators in real-time, providing early warning signals when dependencies approach dangerous levels or when alternative sources become unavailable. Consequently, the monitoring framework enables proactive rather than reactive policy responses to emerging threats.

Strategic Stock Coordination Mechanisms

Member states must coordinate strategic stockpiles to ensure adequate reserves exist for critical materials during supply disruptions. The coordination mechanism prevents duplication of effort while ensuring comprehensive coverage across different materials and regions.

Strategic stockpiling balances cost considerations with security objectives, recognising that maintaining reserves for all critical materials would be economically prohibitive. The coordination system enables efficient resource allocation and shared responsibility among member states.

Large Company Supply Chain Due Diligence Obligations

Companies above specified size thresholds must conduct comprehensive supply chain due diligence, including mapping supplier networks, assessing risk factors, and developing contingency plans for material shortages. These obligations create transparency and accountability in critical materials sourcing.

Due diligence requirements extend beyond immediate suppliers to include upstream mining operations, processing facilities, and transportation networks. Companies must demonstrate understanding of their complete supply chains and ability to respond effectively to potential disruptions.

What Role Does Recycling Play in CRMA's Circular Economy Vision?

Recycling represents the most immediately achievable component of the CRMA's 2030 targets, building on existing waste management infrastructure while creating new opportunities for material recovery and industrial competitiveness. The circular economy approach addresses both supply security and environmental objectives.

25% Recycling Target Implementation Strategy

Achieving the 25% recycling target requires systematic improvements in collection, sorting, processing, and material recovery across multiple industries. The implementation strategy focuses on materials with high recycling potential and established processing technologies.

Collection system improvements must capture materials currently lost to landfills or exported outside the EU. Enhanced sorting technologies will improve material purity and processing efficiency, while processing infrastructure development will expand capacity to handle increased recycling volumes.

According to Aurubis financial reporting, recycling operations face current market challenges including slight revenue declines and competitive pressures. However, the company expects long-term protection for European recycling markets through regulatory measures that prevent material export and strengthen domestic processing capabilities.

Export Restrictions and Customs Duties on Recycling Materials

Export controls on recycling materials aim to ensure adequate domestic supply for European processing facilities while preventing material outflows that undermine circular economy objectives. Customs duties create economic incentives for domestic processing rather than material export.

Aurubis CEO Toralf Haag emphasised that recycling materials are urgently needed to fulfil strong European demand, advocating for export restrictions and customs duties at the EU level. The company maintains active discussions with EU authorities regarding these protective measures, though negotiations have proven challenging as industries and policymakers balance market access with supply security objectives.

Technology Innovation Requirements for Material Recovery

Advanced recovery technologies will be essential for achieving ambitious recycling targets, particularly for complex materials and low-concentration waste streams. Innovation requirements focus on improving recovery rates, reducing processing costs, and expanding the range of recyclable materials.

Research and development priorities include hydrometallurgical processes, biotechnology applications, and artificial intelligence systems for waste sorting and material identification. These technological advances will determine whether the 25% recycling target translates into genuine supply chain benefits or merely statistical compliance.

Which Countries and Regions Will Be Most Affected by CRMA Trade Policies?

The CRMA's implementation will reshape global trade relationships and create new patterns of competition and cooperation in critical materials markets. Different regions face varying opportunities and challenges depending on their current market positions and strategic relationships with the EU.

China's Dominant Position in Critical Materials Processing

China currently controls significant portions of global critical materials processing capacity, particularly for rare earth elements, battery materials, and specialised alloys. The critical raw materials act 40% processing target directly challenges this dominance by creating alternative European capacity.

Chinese companies may face reduced access to European markets as domestic processing capacity expands and supply chain diversification requirements take effect. However, China's technological advantages and cost competitiveness in processing operations will likely maintain significant market influence despite European efforts to reduce dependencies.

The competitive dynamic between European processing development and Chinese market position will influence global pricing, technology transfer patterns, and investment flows in critical materials industries. These developments parallel broader US‑China trade war impacts on global supply chains and industrial competitiveness.

African Mining Partnerships and Strategic Agreements

African countries with significant critical materials deposits represent important partners for European supply diversification efforts. The CRMA creates incentives for enhanced mining partnerships, infrastructure investment, and technology transfer to African producers.

Countries like the Democratic Republic of Congo (cobalt), Guinea (bauxite), and Morocco (phosphates) could benefit from preferential trade relationships with the EU as European companies seek alternatives to Asian suppliers. However, these partnerships must address environmental standards, labour conditions, and revenue-sharing arrangements to ensure sustainable development.

Latin American Lithium Triangle Implications

Argentina, Bolivia, and Chile possess substantial lithium resources essential for European battery manufacturing and electric vehicle production. The CRMA's implementation could strengthen trade relationships with these countries while creating competition with Asian buyers for limited lithium supplies.

European investment in Latin American lithium processing infrastructure could support both EU strategic objectives and regional economic development. Nevertheless, environmental concerns, indigenous rights issues, and resource nationalism policies in some countries create potential complications for expanded trade relationships.

North American Trade Relationship Adjustments

The United States and Canada possess significant critical materials resources and processing capabilities that could complement European supply diversification efforts. However, US Inflation Reduction Act requirements and Canadian resource policies create potential areas of cooperation and competition.

Transatlantic coordination on critical materials policies could enhance supply security for both regions while creating competitive advantages relative to other global players. However, different regulatory approaches and industrial policy priorities may also create trade tensions or conflicts over access to limited materials supplies.

What Are the Main Implementation Challenges Facing the CRMA?

Despite ambitious objectives and comprehensive regulatory mechanisms, the CRMA faces significant implementation obstacles that could prevent achievement of 2030 targets. Understanding these challenges is essential for realistic assessment of policy effectiveness and potential modifications.

Funding Gaps and Investment Requirements

Achieving CRMA targets requires massive capital investment in mining infrastructure, processing facilities, recycling systems, and technology development. Current funding mechanisms may prove insufficient for the scale of investment needed across multiple industries and member states.

Investment Sector Estimated Requirement (€ Billions) Current Funding Gap Primary Funding Sources Mining Infrastructure 15-25 High Private investment, state aid Processing Facilities 30-50 Very High EU funds, member state support Recycling Systems 10-20 Moderate Mixed public-private R&D and Technology 5-10 Moderate Horizon Europe, national programmes

Private sector investment will be essential but requires confidence in long-term policy stability, market demand, and return on investment. Public funding mechanisms must balance fiscal constraints with strategic necessity, while coordination between EU and member state programmes prevents duplication and ensures comprehensive coverage.

Aurubis reported operating pre-tax earnings of €355 million for the year ended September 30, representing a 14% decline. The company's results reflect challenges including lower concentrate throughput, reduced treatment and refining charges, and higher costs associated with strategic project expansions such as the Bulgaria plant development.

Environmental and Social Acceptance Barriers

Expanded mining and processing activities face significant environmental opposition and social resistance in many European communities. Permitting reforms must balance accelerated approvals with legitimate environmental concerns and stakeholder consultation requirements.

Public acceptance challenges include concerns about environmental impacts, community disruption, and health effects from mining and processing operations. Addressing these concerns requires transparent environmental assessments, community engagement programmes, and comprehensive mitigation measures.

Technical Capacity Building Requirements

Europe's mining and processing industries have declined significantly over recent decades, creating skills gaps and technical capacity limitations that constrain rapid expansion. Rebuilding these capabilities requires comprehensive workforce development and technology transfer programmes.

Educational institutions must develop specialised training programmes for mining engineering, metallurgy, and materials processing. Industry partnerships with universities and research institutions will be essential for building the human capital needed to achieve CRMA objectives.

Permitting Complexity Despite Streamlining Efforts

While the CRMA includes permitting reform provisions, the complexity of mining and processing projects creates inherent challenges for timeline reductions. Environmental assessments, stakeholder consultations, and technical reviews require substantial time regardless of regulatory reforms.

Cross-border projects face additional complexity through multiple jurisdictional requirements and coordination challenges. Even with single points of contact, the technical complexity of critical materials projects may limit the effectiveness of permitting streamlining measures.

How Does the CRMA Compare to Similar Legislation Globally?

The CRMA represents one of several national and regional initiatives addressing critical materials supply security, reflecting growing global recognition of these vulnerabilities. Comparative analysis reveals different approaches and potential areas for international coordination.

US Inflation Reduction Act Critical Minerals Provisions

The US Inflation Reduction Act includes substantial support for domestic critical minerals production and processing, with tax credits and funding programmes designed to reduce dependence on foreign suppliers. The approach emphasises private sector incentives rather than regulatory mandates.

Key differences include the US focus on tax incentives versus EU regulatory requirements, different material classification systems, and varying approaches to international partnerships. Both frameworks aim to reduce dependence on Chinese processing capacity but use different policy tools to achieve these objectives.

China's Rare Earth Export Control Measures

China has implemented comprehensive export control systems for rare earth elements and other critical materials, demonstrating how dominant suppliers can use trade policy to maintain strategic advantages. These measures provide insights into potential responses to European diversification efforts.

Chinese export controls include licensing requirements, quantity restrictions, and quality specifications that influence global market dynamics. Understanding these policies is essential for assessing the effectiveness of European supply diversification strategies.

Australia's Critical Minerals Strategy

Australia's approach emphasises international partnerships, technology development, and downstream processing capacity to capture more value from its substantial critical minerals resources. The critical minerals strategy focuses on building processing capabilities rather than simply exporting raw materials.

Australian policies complement European diversification objectives by providing alternative supply sources and processing partnerships. The alignment between Australian supply capabilities and European demand creates opportunities for enhanced trade relationships.

Canada's Critical Minerals List and Policy Framework

Canada's critical minerals strategy emphasises resource development, Indigenous partnerships, and environmental sustainability while building processing capacity for domestic and export markets. The approach balances resource development with environmental protection and social responsibility.

Canadian policies offer potential synergies with CRMA objectives through complementary supply chains and technology cooperation. However, competition for limited processing capacity and skilled workforce could also create tensions between Canadian domestic priorities and European supply needs.

What Does CRMA Success Look Like for European Businesses?

Successful CRMA implementation will fundamentally transform the operating environment for European businesses across multiple sectors, creating new opportunities while addressing longstanding vulnerabilities in global supply chains.

Reduced Supply Chain Risk Exposure

European companies will benefit from decreased vulnerability to supply disruptions, geopolitical tensions, and price volatility in critical materials markets. Diversified supply sources and domestic processing capacity will provide greater operational stability and planning certainty.

Risk reduction extends beyond material availability to include price stability, quality consistency, and delivery reliability. Companies will be able to develop longer-term strategies without constant concern about supply chain disruptions affecting production schedules and customer commitments.

Enhanced Investment Certainty and Planning Horizons

The CRMA's regulatory framework provides greater certainty for long-term investment planning in materials-intensive industries. Companies can invest in capacity expansion, technology development, and product innovation with confidence in material availability and supply chain stability.

Investment certainty particularly benefits industries with long development cycles and high capital requirements, such as renewable energy infrastructure, electric vehicle manufacturing, and advanced electronics production. The regulatory framework reduces technology risks associated with material availability uncertainties.

Competitive Advantages in Global Markets

European companies with secure access to critical materials will gain competitive advantages over rivals facing supply constraints or higher material costs. Domestic processing capacity and recycling capabilities could provide cost advantages and shorter supply chains.

The competitive benefits extend to export markets where European companies can offer greater supply security and sustainability credentials compared to competitors dependent on less reliable or environmentally problematic supply chains.

Innovation Opportunities in Processing Technologies

CRMA implementation will drive innovation in materials processing, recycling technologies, and alternative material development. European companies that develop advanced processing capabilities could become global technology leaders in critical materials industries.

Innovation opportunities include hydrometallurgical processing, biotechnology applications, artificial intelligence for materials optimisation, and circular economy technologies. These developments could create new export industries and intellectual property advantages for European companies.

Critical Raw Materials Act Implementation: Frequently Asked Questions

When will the CRMA targets be measured and evaluated?

The primary measurement point for CRMA targets occurs in 2030, with intermediate assessments and progress reviews conducted regularly throughout the implementation period. The European Commission will publish annual reports on progress toward targets, including detailed analysis of supply chain developments and policy effectiveness.

Member states must provide regular reporting on national implementation efforts, including permitting timelines, investment approvals, and strategic project development. The evaluation framework includes provisions for policy adjustments if progress toward targets proves insufficient.

Which materials are classified as "strategic" under the Act?

Strategic materials classification focuses on materials essential for emerging technologies, defence applications, and energy transition objectives. The classification system considers economic importance, supply risk, and substitutability factors to determine which materials receive enhanced regulatory protection.

The strategic materials list includes rare earth elements, lithium, cobalt, nickel, and other materials critical for batteries, renewable energy systems, and digital technologies. The classification system allows for regular updates as technology requirements and supply risk assessments evolve.

How will the European Critical Raw Materials Board function?

The European Critical Raw Materials Board provides coordination and oversight for CRMA implementation across member states and industries. The Board includes representatives from member states, industry associations, and technical experts to ensure comprehensive perspective on policy development and implementation.

Board functions include monitoring progress toward targets, coordinating cross-border projects, providing technical guidance on policy implementation, and facilitating information sharing between stakeholders. Furthermore, the Board also advises on strategic project designations and policy adjustments based on implementation experience.

What happens if member states fail to meet 2030 targets?

The CRMA includes provisions for corrective measures if member states fail to achieve 2030 targets, including enhanced monitoring, technical assistance, and potential policy adjustments. The framework emphasises collaborative problem-solving rather than punitive measures.

Failure to meet targets could result in revised implementation strategies, additional EU funding support, or modifications to regulatory requirements based on practical implementation experience. The approach recognises that ambitious targets may require adjustments based on technical and economic realities.

Long-term Implications: Europe's Resource Security Beyond 2030

The CRMA's impact extends far beyond its 2030 targets, establishing institutional frameworks and industrial capabilities that will influence European competitiveness and strategic autonomy for decades. Understanding these longer-term implications is essential for assessing the regulation's true significance.

Geopolitical Shifts in Global Materials Markets

Successful CRMA implementation will contribute to fundamental realignment of global critical materials markets, reducing European dependence on dominant suppliers while creating new patterns of international trade and cooperation. These shifts will influence global pricing, technology transfer, and investment flows.

The geopolitical implications extend beyond Europe to affect relationships between major economies, developing country resource policies, and international cooperation frameworks. European success in building strategic autonomy could encourage similar efforts by other regions, further fragmenting global supply chains.

Technology Innovation Acceleration Potential

CRMA requirements will drive innovation in materials processing, recycling technologies, and alternative material development that could position Europe as a global leader in next-generation materials technologies. These innovations may create new export industries and intellectual property advantages.

Technology leadership in critical materials processing could provide economic benefits extending well beyond supply security objectives, creating high-value industries and export opportunities that enhance European competitiveness in global markets.

Environmental Sustainability Integration

The CRMA's emphasis on recycling and circular economy principles establishes foundations for more sustainable approaches to materials consumption and waste management. Long-term success could demonstrate that strategic autonomy objectives align with environmental protection goals.

Sustainability integration includes reducing environmental impacts of materials extraction and processing while building circular economy capabilities that minimise waste and maximise resource efficiency. These approaches could become models for other regions facing similar challenges.

Next-Generation Critical Materials Identification

Technological evolution will continuously create demand for new materials not currently classified as critical, requiring adaptive policy frameworks and flexible supply chain development capabilities. The CRMA's institutional mechanisms must evolve to address emerging material requirements.

Future critical materials may include quantum computing components, advanced energy storage materials, and specialised alloys for aerospace applications. The regulatory framework must maintain flexibility to address these evolving requirements while building on established capabilities and relationships.

Actual results may vary based on implementation effectiveness, market conditions, and geopolitical developments. Readers should conduct independent research and consult professional advisors before making investment or business decisions based on this information.

title: Indiana's Consumer Data Protection Bill of Rights Explains CDPA
description:
Indiana’s new Consumer Data Protection Act (CDPA) takes effect on January 1, 2026.
It follows other state consumer privacy laws by providing consumers with rights related to the collection and processing of their information.
On November 25, 2025, Indiana’s Attorney General issued a Consumer Data Protection Bill of Rights as “a tool to educate Hoosiers on how the new law works, the rights offered to consumers and the obligations placed on applicable businesses.” The Bill of Rights details core consumer rights under the CDPA and adds specific clarity, examples, and expectations for how businesses should operationalize them.
Companies should also train legal and compliance teams on timely responses to consumer requests.
Indiana’s Consumer Data Protection Bill of Rights is likely to drive public understanding, customer expectations, and regulator priorities.
text:
Indiana’s new Consumer Data Protection Act (CDPA) takes effect on January 1, 2026. It follows other state consumer privacy laws by providing consumers with rights related to the collection and processing of their information. On November 25, 2025, Indiana’s Attorney General issued a Consumer Data Protection Bill of Rights as “a tool to educate Hoosiers on how the new law works, the rights offered to consumers and the obligations placed on applicable businesses.”

The Bill of Rights details core consumer rights under the CDPA and adds specific clarity, examples, and expectations for how businesses should operationalize them. Though the guide is intended to clarify the law for consumers, it also puts businesses on notice about the Indiana Attorney General’s compliance expectations under the privacy law.

Rights Summarized in the Bill

The Bill of Rights outlines 15 protections for Indiana consumers, including rights to delete personal data held by companies, opt out of targeted advertising and data sales, and request a copy of their information in a portable format. Amongst other guidelines:

Consumers can find out if a business is processing their data and request one free copy of their personal data each year;

Consumers can request corrections to inaccurate data, or have their personal data deleted, regardless of its source;

Customers can opt out of targeted advertising, profiling, and sale of their personal data.

Businesses may not discriminate if a consumer exercises their rights, including by changing services, pricing, or quality;

Requests must be addressed within 45 days, with one possible 45-day extension; and

Sensitive data, including health, biometric, immigration, religious, and precise location data, and all data on children under 13, cannot be processed unless the consumer or parent/guardian gives opt-in consent.

A Step-by-Step Consumer Guide

Unlike statutes or regulations, the Bill of Rights gives consumers step-by-step instructions for determining if a business is a “controller” subject to the CDPA, how to exercise their rights, and what to do if their request is denied. Consumers are advised to first confirm whether the CDPA even applies, checking for coverage, exemptions, and whether the business meets the relevant data thresholds. Next, they are encouraged to use the methods described in the company’s privacy notice (such as an online form, email, or mailing address) to submit requests to access, correct, or delete their data. For opt-out requests, such as stopping targeted advertising or the sale of personal data, the Bill of Rights instructs consumers to use specifically provided mechanisms, like opt-out buttons or forms.

If a business denies a request, the Bill outlines how to appeal through the company’s process and reminds consumers that if a company does not comply, the consumer can file a formal complaint with the Attorney General’s office. The document also highlights the need for timely responses and requires companies to provide appeal instructions and reasons for denials.

Takeaways

Make your privacy notice easy to find and understand. Given its ease of use and accessibility, consumers are likely to use this document to evaluate companies’ websites for CDPA compliance. Privacy notices should clearly detail what data is collected, with whom it is shared, and how customers can exercise their rights; and

Build user-friendly request and appeal processes. The Bill of Rights expects companies to provide a clear, practical mechanism for requests. Companies should test their processes to determine whether they are accessible and available in the way consumers are likely to make requests. Companies should also train legal and compliance teams on timely responses to consumer requests.

Indiana’s Consumer Data Protection Bill of Rights is likely to drive public understanding, customer expectations, and regulator priorities. As January 2026 approaches, companies should review and update their privacy practices, notices, and response procedures accordingly.

title: ChargePoint Reports Third Quarter Fiscal Year 2026 Financial Results | Morningstar
description:
"ChargePoint’s third quarter results mark a return to growth, with revenue exceeding expectations,” said Rick Wilmer, CEO at ChargePoint.
Third quarter revenue was $105.7 million, up 6% from $99.6 million in the prior year’s same quarter.
Fourth Quarter of Fiscal 2026 Guidance For the fourth fiscal quarter ending January 31, 2026, ChargePoint expects revenue of $100 million to $110 million.
About ChargePoint ChargePoint has established itself as the leader in electric vehicle (EV) charging innovation since its inception in 2007, long before EVs became widely available.
In the future, ChargePoint may also exclude other expenses it determines do not reflect the performance of ChargePoint’s operating results.
text:
Revenue grew 6% year-over-year to $106 million, above top end of the guidance range

Subscription revenue grew 15% year-over-year to $42 million

GAAP gross margin of 31% and non-GAAP gross margin remains at a record high of 33%

Announces reduction of debt by $172 million, more than 50 percent, post quarter end

ChargePoint Holdings, Inc. (NYSE:CHPT) (“ChargePoint”), a global leader in electric vehicle (EV) charging solutions, today reported results for its third quarter of fiscal year 2026 ended October 31, 2025.

"ChargePoint’s third quarter results mark a return to growth, with revenue exceeding expectations,” said Rick Wilmer, CEO at ChargePoint. “In November, we further strengthened our financial foundation by consummating a successful debt exchange and our ongoing innovation and strategic partnerships, especially with Eaton, position us to accelerate growth and lead the future of e-mobility. We remain committed to delivering value for our customers and shareholders as we execute on our three-year plan and advance the industry.”

Third Quarter Fiscal 2026 Financial Overview

Revenue. Third quarter revenue was $105.7 million, up 6% from $99.6 million in the prior year’s same quarter. Networked charging systems revenue for the third quarter was $56.4 million, up 7% from $52.7 million in the prior year’s same quarter. Subscription revenue was $42.0 million, up 15% from $36.4 million in the prior year’s same quarter.

Gross Margin. Third quarter GAAP gross margin was 31% as compared to 23% in the prior year's same quarter, and non-GAAP gross margin was 33% as compared to 26% in the prior year's same quarter primarily due to subscription revenue growth as a percentage of total revenue and improvement in subscription margins.

Operating Expenses. Third quarter GAAP operating expenses were $76.8 million, down 16% from $91.0 million in the prior year's same quarter. Non-GAAP operating expenses were $57.5 million, down 2% from $58.6 million in the prior year's same quarter.

Net Income/Loss. Third quarter GAAP net loss was $52.5 million, down 32% from $77.6 million in the prior year's same quarter. Additionally, non-GAAP pre-tax net loss was $30.2 million, down 26% from $40.7 million in the prior year's same quarter and non-GAAP adjusted EBITDA loss was $19.4 million, down 32% from $28.6 million in the prior year's same quarter.

Liquidity. As of October 31, 2025, cash and cash equivalents on the balance sheet was $180.9 million.

Shares Outstanding. As of October 31, 2025, the Company had approximately 24 million shares of common stock outstanding.

For reconciliation of GAAP and non-GAAP results, please see the tables below.

Business Highlights

In November 2025, ChargePoint strengthened its balance sheet through a significant debt reduction, resulting in a near term reduction of its total outstanding debt by $172 million, or more than 50%.

ChargePoint released the new ChargePoint Platform, its next-generation flexible software solution designed to provide real-time insights, monitor station performance, adjust pricing, and respond to customer needs.

ChargePoint was awarded a Sourcewell cooperative purchasing contract to provide EV charging solutions to public agencies in the U.S. and Canada, representing ChargePoint’s third consecutive agreement with Sourcewell, dating back to 2017.

Fourth Quarter of Fiscal 2026 Guidance

For the fourth fiscal quarter ending January 31, 2026, ChargePoint expects revenue of $100 million to $110 million.

Conference Call Information

ChargePoint will host a webcast today at 1:30 p.m. Pacific / 4:30 p.m. Eastern to review its third quarter fiscal year 2026 financial results.

A live webcast of the conference call will be available at https://events.q4inc.com/attendee/848693269. Participants can also access the conference call by dialing +1 (800) 715-9871 (North America toll free) or + 1 (646) 307-1963 (international) and Conference ID 1744120. A replay will be available after the conclusion of the webcast and archived for one year. A copy of this press release with the financial results and supplemental financial information will be also available on ChargePoint’s investor relations website (investors.chargepoint.com).

About ChargePoint

ChargePoint has established itself as the leader in electric vehicle (EV) charging innovation since its inception in 2007, long before EVs became widely available. The company provides comprehensive solutions tailored to the entire EV ecosystem, from the grid to the dashboard of the vehicle. The company serves EV drivers, charging station owners, vehicle manufacturers, and similar types of stakeholders. With a commitment to accessibility and reliability, ChargePoint’s extensive portfolio of software, hardware, and services ensures a seamless charging experience for drivers across North America and Europe. ChargePoint empowers every driver in need of charging access, connecting them to over 1.3 million public and private charging ports worldwide. ChargePoint has facilitated the powering of more than 16 billion electric miles, underscoring its dedication to reducing greenhouse gas emissions and electrifying the future of transportation. For further information, please visit the ChargePoint pressroom or the ChargePoint Investor Relations site. For media inquiries, contact the ChargePoint press office.

Forward-Looking Statements

This press release contains forward-looking statements that involve risks, uncertainties, and assumptions including statements regarding our projected revenue for the fourth quarter of fiscal year 2026. There are a significant number of factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from the statements made in this press release, including: macroeconomic trends including changes in or sustained inflation, interest rate volatility, increased tariffs or other events beyond our control on the overall economy which may reduce demand for our products and services; geopolitical events and conflicts; adverse impacts to our business and those of our customers and suppliers, including due to supply chain disruptions, component shortages, and associated logistics expense increases; our limited operating history as a public company; our ability as an organization to successfully acquire, integrate or partner with other companies, products or technologies in a successful manner such as our partnership efforts with Eaton Corporation; our dependence on widespread acceptance and adoption of EVs, including any delays or modifications to auto manufacturers' plans and strategies to transition to predominately manufacture EVs and any corresponding decreased demand for installation of charging stations; our current dependence on sales of charging stations for the majority of our revenues; overall demand for EV charging and the potential for reduced demand for EVs if governmental policies, rebates, tax credits and other financial incentives are reduced, modified or eliminated or governmental mandates to increase the use of EVs or decrease the use of vehicles powered by fossil fuels, either directly or indirectly through mandated limits on carbon emissions, are reduced, modified or eliminated; our ability, and our reliance on our customers, to successfully implement, construct and manage state, federal and local charging infrastructure programs in accordance with the respective terms of such program in order to validly secure and obtain awarded funding and win additional grant opportunities; our reliance on contract manufacturers, including those located outside the United States, may result in supply chain interruptions, delays and expense increases which may adversely affect our sales, revenue and gross margins; our ability to expand our operations and market share in Europe; the need to attract additional fleet operators as customers; potential adverse effects on our revenue and gross margins due to delays and costs associated with new product introductions, such as our new AC and Express DC fast charging product architecture featuring bidirectional charging, inventory obsolescence, component shortages and related expense increases; the ability or success of our new AC and Express DC fast charging product architecture to result in an increased demand for charging products by commercial, residential and fleet charging customers; adverse impact to our revenues and gross margins if customers increasingly claim clean energy credits and, as a result, they are no longer available to be claimed by us; the effects of competition; risks related to our dependence on our intellectual property; and the risk that our technology could have undetected defects or errors. Additional risks and uncertainties that could affect our financial results are included under the captions “Risk Factors” and “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations” in our Form 10-Q filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission (the “SEC”) on September 8, 2025, which is available on our website at investors.chargepoint.com and on the SEC’s website at www.sec.gov. Additional information will also be set forth in other filings that we make with the SEC from time to time. All forward-looking statements in this press release are based on information available to us as of the date hereof, and we do not assume any obligation to update the forward-looking statements provided to reflect events that occur or circumstances that exist after the date on which they were made, except as required by applicable law.

Use of Non-GAAP Financial Measures

ChargePoint has provided financial information in this press release that has not been prepared in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles in the United States (“GAAP”). ChargePoint uses these non-GAAP financial measures internally in analyzing its financial results. ChargePoint believes that the use of these non-GAAP financial measures is useful to investors to evaluate ongoing operating results and trends and believes they provide meaningful supplemental information to investors regarding ChargePoint’s underlying operating performance because they exclude items ChargePoint believes are unrelated to, and may not be indicative of, its core operating results.

The presentation of these non-GAAP financial measures is not meant to be considered in isolation or as a substitute for comparable GAAP financial measures and should be read only in conjunction with ChargePoint’s consolidated financial statements prepared in accordance with GAAP. A reconciliation of ChargePoint’s historical non-GAAP financial measures to their most directly comparable GAAP measures has been provided in the financial statement tables included in this press release, and investors are encouraged to review these reconciliations.

Non-GAAP Gross Profit (Gross Margin). ChargePoint defines non-GAAP gross profit as gross profit excluding stock-based compensation expense, amortization expense of acquired intangible assets and restructuring costs for severances and employment-related termination costs, and facility and other contract terminations. Non-GAAP gross margin is non-GAAP gross profit as a percentage of revenue.

Non-GAAP Cost of Revenue and Operating Expenses (includes Non-GAAP research and development, Non-GAAP sales and marketing and Non-GAAP general and administrative). ChargePoint defines non-GAAP cost of revenue and operating expenses as cost of revenue and operating expenses excluding stock-based compensation expense, amortization expense of acquired intangible assets, restructuring costs for severances and employment-related termination costs, and facility and other contract terminations, and non-cash charges related to tax liabilities and litigation settlements, including associated non-recurring legal expenses and professional service fees.

Non-GAAP Net Loss. ChargePoint defines non-GAAP net loss as net loss excluding stock-based compensation expense, amortization expense of acquired intangible assets, restructuring costs for severances and employment-related termination costs, and facility and other contract terminations, and non-cash charges related to tax liabilities and litigation settlements, including associated non-recurring legal expenses and professional service fees. These amounts reflect the impact of any related tax effects. Non-GAAP pre-tax net loss is non-GAAP net loss adjusted for provision for income taxes.

Non-GAAP Adjusted EBITDA Loss. ChargePoint defines non-GAAP adjusted EBITDA loss as net loss excluding stock-based compensation expense, amortization expense of acquired intangible assets, restructuring costs for severances and employment-related termination costs, and facility and other contract terminations, non-cash charges related to tax liabilities and litigation settlements, including associated non-recurring legal expenses and professional service fees, and further adjusted for provision of income taxes, depreciation, interest income and expense, and other income and expense (net).

Investors are cautioned that there are a number of limitations associated with the use of non-GAAP financial measures to analyze financial results and trends. In particular, many of the adjustments to ChargePoint’s GAAP financial measures reflect the exclusion of items that are recurring and will be reflected in its financial results for the foreseeable future, such as stock-based compensation, which is an important part of ChargePoint’s employees’ compensation and impacts hiring, retention and performance. Furthermore, these non-GAAP financial measures are not based on any standardized methodology prescribed by GAAP, and the components that ChargePoint excludes in its calculation of non-GAAP financial measures may differ from the components that other companies exclude when they report their non-GAAP results. In the future, ChargePoint may also exclude other expenses it determines do not reflect the performance of ChargePoint’s operating results.

title: AI model helps geothermal energy company with big discovery in Nevada - Axios
description:
A geothermal energy company announced Thursday that it has discovered — with AI's help — the first commercially viable system of its kind in over 30 years.
Driving the news: The Nevada formation, dubbed "Big Blind," had no surface signs of geothermal activity or any prior history of exploration.
They fed data into Zanskar's AI prediction engine, which helped narrow down the list of options.
Context: The Big Blind discovery follows Zanskar's work at two other geothermal sites — Pumpernickel in northern Nevada and Lightning Dock in New Mexico.
Congress and the Trump administration strongly support geothermal energy.
text:
A geothermal energy company announced Thursday that it has discovered — with AI's help — the first commercially viable system of its kind in over 30 years.

Why it matters: Zanskar Geothermal and Minerals officials said the underground find, in a remote area of western Nevada, offers fresh evidence that geothermal can become an attractive option to meet soaring U.S. energy demand.

Geothermal is the rare alternative energy source with wide bipartisan backing. Democrats are attracted to its zero-emissions footprint, while Republicans like its potential to offer round-the-clock power.

Driving the news: The Nevada formation, dubbed "Big Blind," had no surface signs of geothermal activity or any prior history of exploration.

Zanskar scientists used computer models to locate a geothermal anomaly that indicated exceptionally high heat flow at the site.

They fed data into Zanskar's AI prediction engine, which helped narrow down the list of options.

Zoom in: The result led to "fewer bad wells" being drilled, Joel Edwards, Zanskar's co-founder and chief technology officer, told Axios. That reduces the cost of the projects, he said.

Carl Hoiland, the company's other co-founder and CEO, said AI technology "has allowed us to target deeper and more precisely."

"The analogy here is really every other natural-resource industry, from oil to minerals to shale gas," he said. "They all started on what was at the surface and over time got better at going deeper."

Context: The Big Blind discovery follows Zanskar's work at two other geothermal sites — Pumpernickel in northern Nevada and Lightning Dock in New Mexico.

Unlike Big Blind, both sites had been known to have evidence of geothermal activity, but neither had been fully examined to identify their potential.

What's next: The company plans to seek permits to develop Big Blind into a commercial venture. It hopes the site will provide power by later this decade.

The big picture: The International Energy Agency predicted that geothermal could meet up to 15% of global power demand growth through 2050 — but said greater government policy support, specialized labor, and other boosts will be necessary.

Congress and the Trump administration strongly support geothermal energy. Energy Secretary Chris Wright in March called it "an awesome resource that's under our feet" that could provide the power needed for AI innovation.

The giant tax and spending bill that President Trump signed into law this summer cut tax credits for many renewable energy tax incentives but preserved them for geothermal.

The bottom line: "If you sort of read the tea leaves in the public space, the perception is that naturally occurring systems are tapped out," Edwards said.

"This is sort of showing that, actually, there's a wave of these things coming, and this is just the beginning."

title: Google's Data Center: What the build could mean for Fort Wayne | WBOI
description:
To understand the opposition to the build, first, a look at how the data center came to Fort Wayne, when it was known only as “Project Zodiac.” How the data center came to Fort Wayne In October of 2023, what was then described as an “unnamed Fortune 100 company” proposed a data center campus around Adams Center and Paulding roads, using nearly 900 acres of land and requiring an annexation of more than 700 acres into Fort Wayne.
And in cases like Fort Wayne, the company then asks for more of the old energy sources.
A large investment to the city When city officials approved the Google data center for southeast Fort Wayne, they agreed to a somewhat unusual tax abatement.
In April of 2024, the data center broke ground and, at that groundbreaking, announced initial investments to the Fort Wayne Early Learning Center and Just Neighbors Interfaith Homeless Network.
In Fort Wayne, the Google data center’s developer’s original plan included 34 emergency diesel generators and took about three and three-quarters acres in wetlands.
text:
While opposition to data centers continues to grow, including here in northeast Indiana, Allen County's project is already well into construction.

A few weeks ago, in the middle of November, more than a hundred people showed up to make sure the Indiana Department of Environmental Management heard their opposition to a data center being built in southeast Fort Wayne.

“We’re not just here to defend our neighborhoods in the backyard of this data center, we’re here to defend everyone down river," Kelly Atkins said to represenatives from the Indiana Department of Environmental Management at a hearing about the latest request from the Google data center. At the end of the hearing, the crowd of speakers began chanting at the representatives; "Deny, deny, deny."

Hatchworks LLC, a subsidiary of Google, is requesting an additional 143 diesel generators to support the campus.

To understand the opposition to the build, first, a look at how the data center came to Fort Wayne, when it was known only as “Project Zodiac.”

How the data center came to Fort Wayne

In October of 2023, what was then described as an “unnamed Fortune 100 company” proposed a data center campus around Adams Center and Paulding roads, using nearly 900 acres of land and requiring an annexation of more than 700 acres into Fort Wayne.

The months that followed included a “super-voluntary” annexation, land sale and tax abatement approvals. In January 2024, after everything was finalized, the anonymous company’s name was released; Google would be building a data center campus with up to 12 buildings.

Community development director Jonathan Leist recalled how the property sale went through.

“So we sold our portion of the property for a little less than $12 million, $11.4 (million) I believe, something like that," Leist said. "So that was over and above our last appraisal that we had of the property. So definitely market rate on the land sale.”

In December 2023, Mayor Sharon Tucker was still serving as the city council representative for the sixth district, the area where the data center is currently being built. Following a visit to a similar data center in Columbus, Ohio, at the December 22, 2023 city council meeting, Tucker spoke in favor of approving the project.

“There have been a multitude of bad projects that have tried to be dumped on the south side and I have fought every single one of them," Tucker said at the December 2023 meeting. "This is not one, council, that I’m fighting.”

In her visit to the campus in Columbus, joined by Leist, he said their concerns specifically about sound pollution diminished.

"I think what we saw and heard there was that the only sound really being emitted was construction," Leist said. "Like there was no unique data center sound that I think people in other locations had.”

A change in the energy landscape

The Midwest has become something of a breeding ground for data centers, due to cooler temperatures that require less energy-intensive cooling than Southern states. Great Lakes states like Indiana, Ohio and Michigan have seen a boom in data center builds over the last several years.

There are 72 facilities under construction in Indiana alone.

Earlier this year, the Gerald R. Ford School of Public Policy at the University of Michigan published a study into what happens when data centers come to towns.

The study found that, while many data centers propose to eventually run entirely on green energy, the green energy needed for that much energy running all the time isn’t currently possible.

And in cases like Fort Wayne, the company then asks for more of the old energy sources.

Molly Kleinman is the managing director of the science, technology and public policy program at the Ford School.

“I haven’t seen solid justification for the humungous embrace of as much energy, dirty as it needs to be, as we can get now, and we’ll worry about clean energy down the line," Kleinman said.

But it isn’t just about not using green energy. In many cases, the issue is the way data centers have increased reliance on fossil fuels. In many areas, increased energy needs from data centers are helping coal and gas plants slated for closure to find a second life.

“We’ve seen that data centers have eaten up all of the renewable capacity that the countries added over the last several years, and then gone beyond it," Kleinman said. "They have essentially canceled out all of the gains that we had previously made in renewables.”

Bryce Gustafson is program organizer with Citizens Action Coalition, a consumer and environmental advocacy group based out of Indianapolis.

“This may come as a shock to some people, but Indiana was on a trajectory of getting away from fossil fuels," he said. "This has completely upended that trajectory.”

Indiana Michigan Power just got permission to acquire an existing 870-megawatt gas-fired power plant in Ohio. NIPSCO announced plans in September to build a natural gas plant, through separate company NIPSCO GenCo, to address the increased needs from data centers throughout the state.

A large investment to the city

When city officials approved the Google data center for southeast Fort Wayne, they agreed to a somewhat unusual tax abatement. Fort Wayne community development director Jonathan Leist explains;

"We knew we were up against some other locations, some other states, so we wanted to be competitive. And so rather than our traditional phase in which has a lower amount in the beginning of taxes paid and a higher amount abated, the company, they were comfortable, and we were comfortable with a 50% kind of across the board, which actually ends up being about the same amount as you would get on a 10 year.”

That means that in the year 2025, it changed how the property was evaluated and Google is expected to pay $1 million in property taxes this year. In an area of the city that’s already facing a $3 million cut in city investments, that $1 million is significant.

And, at the end of the full build on the property, Google will generate about $5.9 million per year in property taxes, according to Leist.

“So in this case, a very large investment," he said. "Larger than probably anything we had seen at least in the last five years, for sure, probably 10 years or more.”

In the nearly two years since the project was approved, Google has invested money through grants and donations into the community.

In April of 2024, the data center broke ground and, at that groundbreaking, announced initial investments to the Fort Wayne Early Learning Center and Just Neighbors Interfaith Homeless Network.

In October of this year, the Allen County Public Library received a $35,000 grant from Google for the Rolland Center for Lincoln Research.

Bryce Gustafson, program organizer with Citizens Action Coalition, says companies should give back to the communities they’re building in, but he questioned if what they’re giving is enough.

“I don’t begrudge that but, also, you have to take into account how much money they’re gonna save at the state-level through state sales tax exemptions," Gustafson said. "It would be great to have those numbers to compare because in some situations I’ve seen where ‘we’re gonna give half a million dollars a year here,’ or ‘a million dollars there.’ In the grand scheme of things that’s a nickel to them.”

The environmental risks that data centers bring

With the benefit of economic impact comes potential environmental risks.

In Fort Wayne, the Google data center’s developer’s original plan

included 34 emergency diesel generators and took about three and three-quarters acres in wetlands. This year, developers were approved to take nearly 10 additional wetlands. They’ve more than quadrupled their request for diesel generators, now asking for an additional 143.

“Eighteen months ago, they knew, or should have known, at that time, that that was not enough to sustain their operations. Which means they submitted something that is in bad faith at best," Gina Burgess said.

Burgess showed up to speak at the hearing with the Indiana Department of Environmental Management about the request for more generators.

About 75 people spoke at that meeting, which took place in mid-November, but more than a hundred signed up to speak before the meeting ran out of time.

Every single person who spoke encouraged IDEM to deny the permit.

Resident Danielle Doepke spoke specifically about the health risks the diesel generators pose.

“Diesel exhaust has been classified as a group one carcinogen by internation and national organizations, meaning it is a definite cause of cancer in human," Doepke said. "Studies have found links between diesel exhaust and cancers of the lung, bladder, esophagus, stomach, pancreas, as well as blood cancers like lymphomas and leukemias."

Residents, especially those who live on the south side, expressed concern about air pollution from the generators. Designated as emergency generators, they are only allowed to run them 100 hours a year, about four total days.

The AI "bubble"

In September, a report found construction spending on data centers was at an all-time high of $40 billion in the U.S.

Molly Kleinman is with the Gerald R. Ford School of Public Policy at the University of Michigan, which has been researching data centers. She says there’s a concern that most of these data centers are being built to support tech companies’ AI features and what might happen when the “AI bubble” pops.

"We’re hearing more and more experts weigh in that the way these giant data centers are being funded is not sustainable and, at some point, bubble’s pop.”

A response from city council

In October, WANE15 reported language in the contract between the city and DMI FW LLC, which bought the property for Hatchworks LLC, a subsidiary of Google, included a promise the city wouldn’t turn against Google if public opinion does.

While it makes sense from a business standpoint, Bryce Gustafson with Citizens Acton Coalition said it risks public officials losing their power to listen to the public.

“Normal people just don’t have the same level of power in these issues, so if your decision makers are taking away their power, the everyday Hoosier; What kind of power do they have?" He said.

In 2023, the city council approved the land sale to Hatchworks LLC unanimously. Though, some members of the current council had no hand in that decision.

Activist groups in Fort Wayne have recruited residents to show up at meetings like the IDEM hearing and city council over the past several weeks. They’ve been holding town halls of their own to share information about the center.

At the final city council meeting in November, residents showed up to offer further public comment to the council about the data center and Google’s request for a further 143 diesel generators.

City council has no power to deny the permit. It’s a decision that is in the hands of IDEM and subject to review by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency.

Despite that, fifth district representative Geoff Paddock, who is serving as council president through the end of the year, announced ahead of the public comment he was sending a letter to the Indiana Department of Environmental Management about the request.

"I am asking them to sit down with us, work with us, the city of Fort Wayne, Google, the Mayor’s office, city council members who may be interested, other interested parties to find an alternative," Paddock said.

Once again, residents expressed their concerns about air pollution...

"I already have to carry an emergency inhaler around with me, everywhere I go," said one young resident who spoke at the meeting. "I don’t really want to go outside and suffocate in the first two seconds after that data center is complete.”

Following public comment, councilmembers-at-large Chambers and Friestroffer agreed to work with Paddock, IDEM and Google to better understand the energy needs and the risks of the generators.

Sixth district councilwoman Rohli Booker attended a townhall put on by advocacy groups earlier in the month as well as the IDEM hearing. She commended those who spoke for their continued advocacy and how it has helped her advocate in meetings with Google.

“There are things that I heard at that IDEM hearing that I was able to share with them – some of the solutions, some of the concerns, some of the health implications – that if I hadn’t attended, I would not have been able to do," Booker said.

Booker took on the role of sixth district representative after the data center was already under way.

Amid public hearings, council meetings and town halls, one voice has been missing from the conversation about the data center – Google.

Mayor Sharon Tucker, who has been a proponent of the build since she was still serving as the city council representative for the 6th district, said she’d like Google to work with the public.

“I do wish our Google partners would do what I’ve done and try to answer those concerns and so that would probably be the one thing that I am disappointed in, that they have not answered those cries of concern," she said.

Google hasn’t returned a request for comment.

Following public comment at the council meeting, Chambers said the city is planning a town hall that she hopes Google will attend.

Elsewhere in Indiana, communities are beginning to reject data center builds. Marshall, White and Putnam counties have enacted moratoriums on data centers until they better understand the impacts of them.

The public comment period on the requested extra diesel generators ended November 17, and IDEM has yet to announce a decision on the permit. Due to the requirement to address all comments received, both in writing and verbally, a representative for IDEM says it may take several months for a final permitting decision to be issued.

title: Western states receive largest share of $4 billion in energy revenue - Nevada Public Radio
description:
U.S. states are getting about $4 billion in payments from the federal government this year from energy development revenue on federal land.
New Mexico continues to receive the largest payments, accounting for nearly 70% of state disbursements.
For Wyoming, the next largest recipient of revenue payments, Smith said the story is all about declining coal revenues.
Utah also saw drops, though it did gain more revenue from geothermal energy production ($5 million).
